course_name: Canvas Hackathon (Professor Wright and Professor Lewis)

items.title: Reading Quiz 4
items.content:
Quiz: Reading Quiz 4

Points: 5.0
Due: 2024-10-02T18:00:00Z

Questions:

Question 1:
What is a Botnet?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • A rouge network
  • A group of Internet-connected computers under the control of a remote hacker [CORRECT]
  • A setup used to launch a man-in-the-middle attack
  • A type of malware

Question 2:
A(n) _____ is a software tool that is used to capture packets from a network.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Sniffer [CORRECT]
  • Botnet
  • Cracker
  • Scanner

Question 3:
Which of the following terms best describes a person with very little hacking skills?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Script Kiddie [CORRECT]
  • NooB
  • Rook
  • Wannabe

Question 4:
Which of the below is NOT an example of a threat?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Alteration threat
  • Disclosure Threat
  • Denial or Distruction Threat
  • Rootkit Threat [CORRECT]

Question 5:
Which of the following impacts availability?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • DDos [CORRECT]
  • Cross-site scripting
  • SQL Injection
  • None of the Above

items.title: Lab 1 Quiz
items.content:
Quiz: Lab 1 Quiz

Description: Quiz to test understanding of Lab 1.
This quiz is designed to test your understanding of Lab 1: Data Gathering and Footprinting of a Website.

Points: 8.0
Due: 2024-09-16T03:59:59Z

Questions:

Question 1:
By its nature, WHOIS information must be:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • encrypted.
  • concealed.
  • kept private.
  • publicly available. [CORRECT]

Question 2:
In the lab, you used __________ from your local computer to capture data about a targeted company that might be useful in performing a potential attack on that company’s corporate website.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Google.com [CORRECT]
  • Yahoo.com
  • Microsoft.com
  • the Windows Start icon

Question 3:
Sam Spade is considered a(n):
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • invasive tool.
  • non-intrusive tool. [CORRECT]
  • ineffective tool.
  • attacking device.

Question 4:
The Internet has always provided the would-be attacker potential access; now it also provides much-welcomed:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • intelligence. [CORRECT]
  • attacks.
  • threats.
  • communication.

Question 5:
The first phase of hacking is the __________ phase, which is designed to gain as much information about a target organization and its systems as possible.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • information
  • identification
  • reconnaissance [CORRECT]
  • follow-up

Question 6:
Which of the following can a hacker derive from the IP address of a target server?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • The physical location of the server’s data center (hosting location) [CORRECT]
  • The physical location of the server’s owner
  • The contact information for the domain
  • The network path that was followed

Question 7:
Which of the following is used to identify the network path that must be followed to reach one system from another?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • WHOIS
  • Sam Spade
  • traceroute [CORRECT]
  • nslookup

Question 8:
Which of the following will return information about the domain owner, including contact names, numbers, addresses, and the names of associated servers?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • WHOIS [CORRECT]
  • Sam Spade
  • traceroute
  • nslookup

items.title: Lab 2 Quiz
items.content:
Quiz: Lab 2 Quiz

Description: Quiz to test understanding of Lab 2: Using Encryption to Enhance Confidentiality and Integrity

Points: 8.0
Due: 2024-09-23T03:59:59Z

Questions:

Question 1:
Cryptography takes human readable information and makes it unreadable “cipher text” which can only be read if:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • it is broadcast over a public network.
  • a digital device is “always on.”
  • it is asymmetric.
  • one possesses the correct key. [CORRECT]

Question 2:
Each time a key pair is created, Kleopatra generates:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • a unique 40-character fingerprint. [CORRECT]
  • a unique 8-digit fingerprint.
  • a test.
  • an expiration date.

Question 3:
How can you verify that the integrity of encrypted files is maintained during the transmission to another user’s computer?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Import the file into Kleopatra and select the Integrity Check option.
  • Right-click the file and select Integrity Check from the context menu.
  • Right-click the file and select Verify from the context menu.
  • Compare the decrypted file’s contents with the contents of the original file. [CORRECT]

Question 4:
How do you encrypt a text message using the keys you created in the lab?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Double-click the file and select Sign and Encrypt from the application menu.
  • Double-click the file and select Encrypt or Decrypt from the application menu.
  • Right-click the file and select Sign and Encrypt from the context menu. [CORRECT]
  • Right-click the file and select Encrypt or Decrypt from the context menu.

Question 5:
If someone sends you his public key and you import it into Kleopatra, will he be able to decrypt the encrypted messages you send him?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Yes because his public key is used by both of you to encrypt and decrypt messages.
  • Only if he also sends you his private key.
  • No because you must provide your private key to any user wanting to decrypt any message encrypted by you.
  • No because you must provide your public key to any user wanting to decrypt any message encrypted by you. [CORRECT]

Question 6:
In Kleopatra, each new certificate is created with no expiration (valid until) date, but you can set an expiration date in the:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Export Secret Details screen.
  • Certificate Creation Wizard.
  • FileZilla Client application.
  • Certificate Details screen. [CORRECT]

Question 7:
Keys are also referred to as:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • secret messages.
  • pairs.
  • certificates. [CORRECT]
  • senders.

Question 8:
Which of the following statements is true regarding symmetric cryptography?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • The sender and receiver use the same key to encrypt and decrypt a given message. [CORRECT]
  • It is quite slow and generally more difficult to implement than asymmetric cryptography.
  • It does not provide confidentiality or integrity.
  • It guarantees authenticity.

items.title: Lab 3 Quiz
items.content:
Quiz: Lab 3 Quiz

Points: 6.0
Due: 2024-10-07T03:59:59Z

Questions:

Question 1:
What type of attack can be used to search for weak login credentials?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • port scanning
  • brute forcing passwords [CORRECT]
  • SQL injections
  • social engineering

Question 2:
Which of the following commands could be used to perform an initial scan of a target host that would have low risk of detection by an EDRS?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • nmap -A IP_ADDRESS -p 80,22
  • hydra -l root -P /path/to/word_list IP_ADDRESS ssh
  • nmap IP_ADDRESS [CORRECT]
  • curl -XGET http://IP_ADDRESS/SQL_INJECTION_TEST

Question 3:
Which of the following is not an endpoint device?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • A software-dependent weapon system
  • A SCADA device in a natural gas distribution network
  • A handheld analog radio [CORRECT]
  • A network-connected drone

Question 4:
Which of the following scenarios is more likely to indicate a system has been compromised?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • a single isolated failed SSH login
  • multiple failed SSH logins from the same IP address
  • multiple failed SSH logins followed by a success, all from the same IP address [CORRECT]
  • a single isolated successful SSH login

Question 5:
Which of these tools would be useful for taking over a target workstation and gaining system privileges?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • nmap
  • metasploit [CORRECT]
  • curl
  • hydra

Question 6:
What is the best description of endpoint systems?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Endpoint systems provide data paths between devices in a network.
  • Endpoint systems are devices that connect to a network. [CORRECT]
  • Endpoint systems make routing decisions within a network.
  • Endpoint systems filter traffic at network boundaries.

items.title: Lab 4 Quiz
items.content:
Quiz: Lab 4 Quiz

Description: Complete the quiz after completing Lab 4.

Points: 5.0
Due: 2024-10-30T03:59:00Z

Questions:

Question 1:
Which of the following statements is true regarding SQL Injection attacks?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • They are extremely difficult to prevent.
  • Their likelihood can be reduced through regular testing. [CORRECT]
  • Their likelihood cannot be reduced through secure software development practices.
  • They are one of the rarest types of web attack

Question 2:
Hackers use __________ to execute arbitrary scripts through the web browser.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • phishing attacks
  • penetration testing
  • SQL Injection
  • cross-site scripting (XSS) [CORRECT]

Question 3:
Which of the following Web forms can be exploited to output passwords, credit card information, and other data?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Those with integrity
  • Those with confidentiality
  • Those that are poorly designed [CORRECT]
  • Those that are properly secured

Question 4:
How can you ensure the confidentiality, integrity, and availability (CIA) of the web application and service?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Symmetric testing
  • Asymmetric testing
  • Penetration testing [CORRECT]
  • Vulnerability testing

Question 5:
In the lab, what did you do before attempting the script tests that exposed the vulnerabilities?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Set the security level of penetration testing to high.
  • Set the security level of penetration testing to low.
  • Set the security level of Damn Vulnerable Web Application (DVWA) to high.
  • Set the security level of DVWA to low. [CORRECT]

items.title: Lab 5 Quiz
items.content:
Quiz: Lab 5 Quiz

Description: Complete the quiz after completing Lab 5.

Points: 6.0
Due: 2024-10-28T03:59:59Z

Questions:

Question 1:
How can an attacker assess the effectiveness of a DoS attack?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • monitor the traffic on the target's network interface
  • monitor the traffic on the target network's gateway device
  • attempt legitimate activity on the target during a trial attack [CORRECT]
  • monitor network traffic on the attacking device

Question 2:
What is the best description of most of the machines involved in a typical botnet?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • machines owned by the attacker and distributed globally
  • machines owned by the attacker and housed in a single data center
  • machines not owned by the attacker, but compromised to allow the attacker to run arbitrary programs [CORRECT]
  • machines not owned by the attacker, but hired by them to run arbitrary programs

Question 3:
Which of the following is not usually a primary role of the command-and-control server for a botnet?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • to conduct attacks directly against the target [CORRECT]
  • to provide payloads to machines in the botnet
  • to establish a channel of communication with the machines in the botnet
  • to receive reports of results from the botnet

Question 4:
Why does using a botnet allow an attack to overwhelm a target more easily than attacking from a single machine?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • It is easier to coordinate an attack involving many machines.
  • The total capacity for bandwidth and connections of the botnet can be much higher than the capacity of the target. [CORRECT]
  • The botnet can use machines that are globally distributed.
  • The botnet can include machines with multiple operating systems.

Question 5:
Which of the following tools is most helpful for identifying potential attack vectors on a target?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • ping
  • hping3
  • nmap [CORRECT]
  • ssh

Question 6:
Which of the following methods would you employ to issue commands to a botnet from a C2 (command-and-control) server?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • make a dropper script available for download
  • deploy an exploit to compromise new machines
  • listen for messages on a private IRC channel
  • send messages to a private IRC channel [CORRECT]

items.title: Lab 6 Quiz
items.content:
Quiz: Lab 6 Quiz

Points: 7.0
Due: 2024-11-11T04:59:59Z

Questions:

Question 1:
A promising victim at a target company has been identified. The victim has received some training on basic computer security. Which of the following techniques would be the best approach in a spear fishing attack to deploy a ransomware dropper script?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • a threatening message telling the victim to click a link
  • a message that appears to come from a manager asking the victim to view a new policy in a PDF [CORRECT]
  • a message with a link about a seemingly harmless subject that is not work-related
  • a message that appears to come from security personnel with an attached executable

Question 2:
An attacker has sent out a mass email to attempt ransomware attacks on a target company. The ransomware generates a symmetric key to encrypt the victim's data. It generates an asymmetric key pair and uses the public key to encrypt the symmetric key. The malware server receives the information needed to restore the victim's data and stores it in a log file. What does the attacker need to send to a victim if they choose to honor the ransom demand?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • the asymmetric private key [CORRECT]
  • the asymmetric public key
  • the symmetric key
  • both the symmetric key and the asymmetric private key

Question 3:
What is the major difference between a ransomware attack and other types of cybersecurity threats?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • A ransomware attack is performed in a way that is impossible to detect.
  • A ransomware attack is combined with a promise to reverse the damage when a payment is received. [CORRECT]
  • A ransomware attack involves the attacker physically abducting a member of the target organization.
  • A ransomware attack always requires user interaction.

Question 4:
What is the most likely primary purpose of a ransomware attack being conducted against an enemy during a conflict?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Locating key facilities of the enemy's infrastructure.
  • Disrupting the infrastructure of the enemy. [CORRECT]
  • Extracting data about the enemy's actions.
  • Getting money from the enemy.

Question 5:
Which of the following actions is a reasonable mitigation for most companies that can be effective at preventing ransomware attacks from succeeding?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Developing a detailed response plan for ransomware attacks
  • Disabling all internet access from employees' computers and devices
  • Training all personnel to spot risky emails and links [CORRECT]
  • Hiring a security analyst to monitor all network traffic manually

Question 6:
How can the compromise of a single machine in a target network using a ransomware attack result in the disruption of many parts of the victim's systems?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Once the ransom is paid, it enables the attack to spread rapidly to other machines.
  • The success of a single attack can require the victim to disable or restrict the use of many more machines until a thorough damage assessment can be completed. [CORRECT]
  • Attempting to mitigate a ransomware attack results in the immediate spread to new machines.
  • A ransomware attack is more visible, so it creates more panic.

Question 7:
Which of the following targets would be the most promising to a threat actor planning a new ransomware attack through spear phishing?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • the email address of a seasoned system administrator with detailed social media data
  • a list of all the email addresses at the target company
  • the email address of a newly hired security analyst with detailed social media data [CORRECT]
  • the email address of a C-level executive

items.title: Reading Quiz 3
items.content:
Quiz: Reading Quiz 3

Points: 5.0
Due: 2024-09-18T18:00:00Z

Questions:

Question 1:
Three of the main types of cyptosystems discussed in the chapter are:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Symmetric Key Encryption [CORRECT]
  • Asymmetric Key Encryption [CORRECT]
  • Padlock Encyyption
  • Hashing [CORRECT]
  • Guttering-Schnell Encryption

Question 2:
Another name for an algorithm is a cipher.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • True [CORRECT]
  • False

Question 3:
It would be harder to break 40 bit encryption than 256 bit encryption schemes.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • True
  • False [CORRECT]

Question 4:
Cryptography can provide information security in four ways:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Confidentiality—Ensures that only authorized subjects can access d [CORRECT]
  • Authenticity—Ensures that data can be verified as valid and can be truste [CORRECT]
  • Integrity—Ensures that only authorized subjects can modify da [CORRECT]
  • Nonrepudiation—Provides positive evidence that a message or action originated with a certain party [CORRECT]
  • Transparency - Data can be clearly identified by both the sender and the receiver
  • Reciprocity - Keys can be shared and reshared without concern about their validity

Question 5:
The chapter included a section on future forms of cryptography, which included the concept of quantum computing cryptography.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • True [CORRECT]
  • False

Service-level agreement (SLA)—This type of agreement is a a formal contract can include:

Answer Choices:

Question 3:
Which of the following manages the goals and objectives in organizations.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Policies [CORRECT]
  • MOUs
  • SLAs

Question 4:
Security administration is (NOTE - The pages assigned for this quiz were off by 4, so ALL responses to this question will be treated as correct):

Answer Choices:

  • A library of the policies. [CORRECT]

Which of the following is NOT a means to ensure compliance?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:

  • Compliance Liaison

items.title: Reading Quiz 8
items.content:
Quiz: Reading Quiz 8

Points: 5.0
Due: 2024-12-02T19:00:00Z

Questions:

Question 1:
To stay safer from computer monitoring, it is important to:
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Stay away from free software downloads, as they are often loaded with adware [CORRECT]
  • Do not open attachents from people you do not know and trust [CORRECT]
  • Take advantage of free utilities that you find using your search engine
  • Ignore software patches and updates for programs that you use

Question 2:
What Amendment to the United States Constitution is most important to personal privacy?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • 4th [CORRECT]
  • 1st
  • 12th
  • 7th

Question 3:
Which of the following are not good ideas to protect yourself when using cloud computing accounts?
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Link as many of your social media accounts together to make it easier to make posts across platforms [CORRECT]
  • Use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) whenever possible
  • Use a different and strong password for every cloud account
  • Have more than one email address that you can use to separate your socail media accounts from your home email and online purchases

Question 4:
If there are criminal charges against you, almost all evidence posted on the internet is discoverable and police can obtain the information legally.
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • True [CORRECT]
  • False

Question 5:
The following technologies can be used to track your smartphone (Choose all that apply):
Points: 1.0

Answer Choices:
  • Cellular Towers [CORRECT]
  • GPS [CORRECT]
  • Wifi [CORRECT]
  • Blutooth [CORRECT]

items.title: Case 3: Social Engineering
items.content:
Assignment: Case 3: Social Engineering

Due: 2024-11-04T04:59:00Z
Points: 10.0
Submission Types: discussion_topic

Description:
Please answer these discussion questions assuming you will be asked about your answers in class. For example, make sure all answers are something you could speak to if asked to elaborate. 
Requirements:

You must post your answer before seeing the other students' replies.
Answer all questions in a single post.
The first two answers should be no more than a paragraph [5 to 7 sentences]. The second answer will be double and can include uploaded figures or tables.  

Questions:

What should the information security team’s priorities be in the upcoming months, and what steps should they take to implement these changes? [1 Point]
Discuss the concept of organizational resilience in the context of mitigating cybersecurity risks. How can UVA develop a culture that emphasizes cybersecurity awareness and resilience among its stakeholders? [2 Points]
The attached data set has data from a recent phishing simulation. Describe briefly what you found in this data set and what actions you would take based on this data. [5 Points] 

Points: [8 points this discussion point; 2 points for class discussion]

items.title: Mini Case Writeup
items.content:
Assignment: Mini Case Writeup

Points: 14.0
Submission Types: online_upload

Description:
This mini-case assignment requires you to develop a written teaching case focused on a cybersecurity topic that aligns with the course objectives. The assignment has three components: the written teaching case, a teaching note, and an in-class presentation. The teaching case should be no less than five pages and should provide a detailed exploration of a cybersecurity issue relevant to the concepts discussed in this course. The accompanying teaching note should offer guidance on how to effectively teach the case in a classroom setting. Finally, you will present your case to the class in a 15-minute presentation, which will form part of your overall grade. 

Component 1: Written Teaching Case (min. 5 pages) 
Your teaching case should present a real-world scenario or hypothetical situation that illustrates a cybersecurity challenge. The case should be well-researched, providing a comprehensive overview of the issue, the key players involved, and the decisions that need to be made. It should be engaging and thought-provoking, encouraging students to apply their knowledge of cybersecurity principles, network security, threat analysis, or incident response. The case can be based on real events or can be fictional.  

Component 2: Teaching Note (min. 2 pages) 
The teaching note is a crucial part of the assignment that helps instructors facilitate discussion and learning from the case. It should provide an overview of the case, key learning objectives, discussion questions, and potential answers or directions for the discussion. The teaching note should also suggest ways to integrate the case into the broader context of the course and how it aligns with the specific learning objectives. 

Component 3: In-Class Presentation 
You will present your teaching case to the class in a 15-minute presentation at an assigned time. This presentation is designed to simulate the process of teaching the case and leading a classroom discussion. You should summarize the key points of your case, introduce the discussion questions, and guide your peers through the decision-making process presented in the case. The presentation will be evaluated based on clarity, engagement, and the effectiveness of your teaching strategy.

items.title: Mini Case Presentation
items.content:
Assignment: Mini Case Presentation

Points: 6.0
Submission Types: online_upload

Description:
Presentation Guidelines: 
Time Management: Ensure that your presentation fits within the 15-minute time frame, allowing time for introducing the case, posing questions, and engaging the class. 
Engagement: Actively engage your peers in the discussion by asking questions and encouraging participation. 
Clarity: Present the case clearly, with well-organized content and logical flow. 
Teaching Strategy: Demonstrate effective teaching techniques, such as summarizing key points, asking open-ended questions, and facilitating discussion.

items.title: How can I use Canvas to enhance my course design?
items.content:
Lecture: How can I use Canvas to enhance my course design?

As an educator, you are both a curator and creator of course content. Following common universal design practices will help ensure that your students can access this content regardless of their abilities, and foster a positive learning environment for all. Modules can be a great way to organize assignments, quizzes, and pages with media for your students. In the sections below, you can find tips for presenting assignments, documents, and other media clearly. 
Step 1: Consider structure
The first step is to decide how you want to organize your course content for students. Is there a structure that is familiar to your students, whether it be from your department, school, or field of study? Some examples of structure include:

Weeks or classes
Topics or units
Chapters in a book

Consider what system would make it easiest for you and your students to navigate course content.
Step 2: Get good content
The second step in course development is often curating content. This could involve gathering or creating materials, such as:

Articles
Documents
Textbooks
Website links
 Images, videos, and other media

When finding and creating content, we recommend checking that it is accessible to all students, regardless of their strengths and abilities. For more information, see What does it mean to make content accessible?
Tip: Contact subject librarians, instructional designers, and the Student Disability Access Center for help.
Step 3: Create assessment opportunities
Determine how you want to assess your students, providing multiple ways of checking student understanding. 

Formative assessments: Low-stakes activities that give students a chance to demonstrate their understanding while giving both students and instructors the opportunity to identify learning gaps. For more information, see the A&S Learning Design & Technology team's Formative Assessments overview. Tools you could use for formative assessments include:

Assignments
External tools, such as VoiceThread, Annotations (Hypothesis), or Kaltura Video Quizzes
Discussions
Quizzes

Summative assessments: Higher-stakes activities that evaluate a student's proficiency after the completion of an instructional unit. For more information, see the A&S Learning Design & Technology team's Summative Assessments overview.  Tools you could use for summative assessments include:

Quizzes
Assignments
External tools, such as Gradescope or Peer Review

Step 4: Build modules
Using the structure from step 1 above, create modules in your Canvas course and add your content to pages in the modules.

Create a module.
Add a page to the module.
Use headings to structure the page and present concepts in small "bite-sized" pieces.
Guide your students with clear and concise instructions.
Make navigation as simple as possible by adding links to activities (e.g., assignments, discussions, quizzes) on the page. Create accessible links with uniquely descriptive link text. Examples of meaningful link text:

"Submit Week 3 Essay" - link to an assignment.
"Intro to Accessibility (PDF)" - link to an article
 "Access the Oxford English Dictionary online" - link to a website

Provide context around embedded content. For example, if you embed a lecture video, provide a brief description of the content so that students will know what to expect when they watch it. For images, add meaningful text descriptions.

items.title: TWIST Presentation
items.content:
Lecture: TWIST Presentation

The "This Week in Security Tech" (TWIST) are 10-minute (max) presentation that will be done at the beginning of class. Presentations will start at 12:30 pm sharp and end at 12:40 pm sharp.
For this assignment, you and your group will present and develop a report of a topic chosen from a list of options. The presentation should be non-technical and for an executive (C-suite) audience. In preparing your presentation, focus on the following questions to guide the paper and the presentation:
1.    What happened / What is this? 
2.    What is the impact or potential impact?
3.    How can / could risk be mitigated or what is this technology offer?
4.    What are the take-aways that executives would be interested in?
You do not have to answer the question explicitly. They are guideposts.  
Complementarity News Sources:  Although the topic is provided, we ask they you evaluate other published materials when applicable. There is no shortage of news or sources for news on cybersecurity threats.  Some recommended sources include (but in no way are limited to):
1.    Naked Security (nakedsecurity.sophos.com)
2.    Krebs on security (krebsonsecurity.com)
3.    Security Week (securityweek.com)   
Topics: The topics will be selected during the second week of the course.
Requirements (submitted BEFORE the presentation):

PPT or PDF deck
Two-page single spaced memo.

items.title: Mod 1: Cybersecurity Infrastructure - Canvas Hackathon
items.content:
Module: Mod 1: Cybersecurity Infrastructure - Canvas Hackathon

Canvas Hackathon (you should be enrolled as a teacher in this course)

Course description
This course provides a manager’s view of cybersecurity and privacy.  The content of the course gives a broad overview of essential concepts and methods for providing and evaluating security for organizations. This course includes an emphasis on applying analytics to understand cybersecurity threats.  In addition, the course touches on the importance of management and administration, the place information security holds in overall business risk, risk presented by the rise of the IoT, social issues such as individual privacy, and the role of public policy.
